description.value: Silvered religious amulet worn as a pendant, St. Mechtildis on obverse, worn to protect against pestilance and poisoning, European, 19th century

NOTE: THE SA TRANSCRIPTION AND SB DESCRIPTION RECORDED HERE OCCUR ON THIS OBJECT BUT MAY NOT CORRESPOND TO THIS PARTICULAR INSCRIPTION.  THIS IS INSCRIPTION 2 OF 2.  SA = B.MECH TILDIS  S7=   SB =

facilities.summary_title: Science Museum, Medicine: The Wellcome Galleries

name.value: Science Museum, Medicine: The Wellcome Galleries

locations.summary_title: Science Museum, Medicine: The Wellcome Galleries
locations.value: Science Museum, Medicine: The Wellcome Galleries

dimensions.value: length 35 mm; width 20 mm; thickness 2 mm

note.value:
Short research project related to amulets commissioned in 2017 to inform Medicine Galleries project. Researcher Annie Thwaite advised: 

Unlikely that this amulet was solely intended for the plague, as the date given (19th century) does not correlate with any European plague epidemics, and none of the aesthetic features of the amulet demonstrate that it was made exclusively to protect from or heal the plague. On one side it reads ‘Mechtildis’, referring to St. Mechtildis, revered for her mystical gifts and miracles. This would  explain the imagery of her holding an open box. On the reverse, it reads: ‘Patrona contratem pestates et veneficia’ (Patron(ess) against (pestilence?) and poisonings). [Sarah Bond 08/03/18]
